Award.AwardTitle: Mass Rigidity and Curvature Problems in Mathematical Relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Einsteinâ€™s theory of gravity has been a strong driving force for the modern development in several branches of mathematics. Among its profound implications and wide applications, the theory of gravity successfully describes the shape of our universe and predicts celestial objects that were not known to exist, such as black holes. Over the past few decades, remarkable progress using advanced techniques in geometry and analysis has been made to resolve fundamental questions in general relativity, which has also led to the astonishing realization that some celestial objects are governed by the same mathematical principles as daily life objects, such as soap films. This project employs frontier developments in mathematics to investigate those interconnections and to further advance our understanding on the geometric structures of mathematical models of our universe. The project also incorporates mentoring and educational activities to promote geometry, analysis, and their interrelations with other STEM disciplines, to broader communities and to the society.

Because of rapid advancement in geometric analysis in recent years, several longstanding questions in general relativity have been largely resolved. A prominent example is the resolution to the positive mass conjecture, including recent work on the spacetime positive mass theorem. At the same time, those resolutions in general relativity have motivated the development of new and unexpected techniques in geometry and analysis. The goal of this project is to interconnect general relativity with neighboring areas in geometry and analysis where some of innovative techniques can be further developed and applied. The scope of the project is to analyze curvature and geometric structure of initial data sets and their spacetime development, arising from mass minimization problems related to quasi-local mass, to investigate scalar curvature problems for compact manifolds and classification of static manifolds, and to characterize Einstein manifolds from the aspect of hyperbolic and conformal geometry. The project develops new ideas and techniques from differential geometry, analysis, partial differential equations, functional analysis, and calculus of variations to tackle fundamental questions in mathematical relativity and in the neighboring areas of geometry and analysis and is anticipated to have impact in other areas of mathematics and in theoretical physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of Einstein equations in general relativity has significantly advanced geometry and analysis. Over the past four decades, progress in resolving fundamental physical conjectures through geometric analysis has inspired new techniques in these fields, notably regarding the positive mass conjecture. Dr. Huang and their collaborators have made further progress on this conjecture and related problems, introducing new techniques for addressing other fundamental issues.

This award has supported research programs in three general directions. The first is studying minimization problems of mass in general relativity, the second is understanding the deformation of scalar curvature, and the third is investigating Einstein manifolds with boundaries. During the support period, Dr. Huang and her collaborators have resolved several fundamental problems, such as the equality of the positive mass theorem and the existence of Einstein manifolds with boundaries. Progress made on these problems has impacted other areas of mathematics and theoretical physics, for example, the study of compact Einstein manifolds with boundaries arising in the quantum field theory. 

The research has led to several educational activities that train graduate students and promote the knoweledge of geometry and analysis, especially its interconnections with physics, to broader communities of mathematics and physics and more generally to the society. Dr. Huang has made significant efforts to engage in mentoring and educational activities and to disseminate findings supported by this award in an accessible way to students and general audiences. Continuing efforts have been made to promote gender equality in math and to increase awareness of STEM educations to general public, especially to traditionally under-represented groups.
